citeinfo.title: Selected environmental characteristics of sampled sites, watersheds, and riparian zones for the U.S. Geological Survey Regional Stream Quality Assessment, 2013 to 2017

descript.abstract: In 2013, the Regional Stream Quality Assessment (RSQA) study was started as part of the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) National Water-Quality Assessment (NAWQA) project. One of the objectives of the RSQA is to characterize the relationships between water-quality stressors and stream ecology and subsequently determine the relative effects of these stressors on aquatic biota within the streams (Garrett and others, 2017; Journey and others, 2015; Coles and others, 2019; Sheibley and others, 2017; May and others, 2020). The study was implemented in five regions across the United States (U.S.); the Midwest (MSQA) in 2013, the southeast (SESQA) in 2014, the Pacific Northwest (PNSQA) in 2015, the northeast (NESQA) in 2016, and California (CSQA) in 2017. To meet this objective (correlations with and effects of stressors), a framework of fundamental geospatial data was required to develop physical and anthropogenic characteristics of each study region for the watersheds and riparian zones associated with each sampling location. This dataset includes 150 selected environmental characteristics for the 483 sites sampled across all regions of the study. The characteristics were derived over the five years (2013 to 2017) using geospatial summary techniques where spatial information is summarized based on spatial extents such as watersheds. The characteristics were developed using the geospatial data for the location of the water-quality sites, delineations of areas draining to the sites (watershed boundaries, including the boundaries of the lower 5 kilometers [km] of watershed [Lower Basin] for the NESQA and CSQA study regions), and riparian-zone boundaries defined from buffers along digitized riparian reaches (Qi and Nakagaki, 2020). This dataset consists of 3 tables: 1) the main data file containing the environmental characteristics of sites, watersheds (including the boundaries of the lower 5 km of watershed for the NESQA and CSQA study regions), and riparian zones, 2) the data dictionary that describes the variables in the data file, and 3) the full citations associated with the references cited in the data dictionary.
descript.purpose: This dataset was created to support the RSQA objectives where the physical and anthropogenic characteristics in this dataset assist with the statistical analyses and interpretation of stream water-quality and biota data collected for the RSQA study.
descript.supplinf:
All information in these tables are found in this metadata file. The main data file contains three tabs that represent the environmental characteristics calculated for the whole watershed (WatershedData), the characteristics calculated for the riparian zones (RiparianData), and the characteristics calculated for the lower 5km of the watersheds for NESQA and CSQA studies only (LowerBasinData_NESQA_CSQA). Note, in the Process Steps section below, variable names are grouped by the type of processing and the type of variable and may not in the same order as they appear in the data files.
Some variable names contain year values that indicate the year that particular data represent. For example, for the variables representing Runoff there is "Runoff2013, Runoff2014, Runoff2015, Runoff2016, and Runoff2017 that represent the runoff data processed for the particular year in which the study was conducted. The data were represented in 5 columns rather than one because methods and/or data sources could be different as software and data are updated through the years of study. Therefore, for these variables, there may be null values within the column because the data for a particular year were not processed for studies that were not conducted in those years. In the data dictionary, variable names beginning with "r50_" have the same definition as the variable without the prefix but represent the data summarized by riparian zone rather than watershed area. Additionally, the variables beginning with "LB_" have the same definition as the variable without the prefix but represent the data summarized by the lower 5 km of the watershed (Lower Basin) rather than watershed area.
The data dictionary is composed of 13 columns, and can be grouped into three categories: variables, sources, and methods. The variables columns include the name, description, extent, units of measure, and time period. The source columns describe the data source, and the full references for the cited references are found in the citations file. The method columns indicate the manner in which each characteristic was processed. One of the methods columns consists of abbreviated short names, which are explained in Nakagaki and others (2013), a work that accordingly serves as a reference for the overall conceptual description of the methods. Another column shows the names of the actual tools used in the geographic information system (GIS) software. The tools that were used to geoprocess the characteristics are elements of either the ArcToolbox version 10.1, 10.3 or 10.5, a component of the ArcGIS for Desktop (ESRI, 2017) or the NAWQA Area-Characterization Toolbox ("NACT Toolbox") version 2.0 (Price, 2012), originally published by Price and others (2010). The tool names that end with "_nact" in the data dictionary file are from the NACT Toolbox; whereas, all the remaining tools are from the ArcToolbox (ESRI, 2017).
This dataset has been made available in both tab-delimited text format in addition to Microsoft EXCEL.

attracc.attraccr: Results of computations for characteristics were checked visually for selected watersheds, sites, and riparian zones by comparing the site locations, watershed, and riparian-zone boundaries with the geospatial-thematic datasets. In addition, quantitative values were compared (where possible) with previously published values calculated for selected watersheds using the same or similar source data and methods (Falcone, 2011).

dataqual.logic: Some watershed boundaries (MSQA and SESQA) do not coincide with the site location primarily because the water-quality (QW) sampling for the RSQA study did not take place at the same physical location indicated by the geographic coordinates of the USGS station in the National Water Information System (NWIS) database (U.S. Geological Survey, 2016). For the final three study region site locations (PNSQA, NESQA, and CSQA), the longitude and latitude of the sampling location reflect the actual location where the QW sample was collected. Consequently, the location may not match what is in NWIS for all site locations. Additionally, two watersheds in the state of Washington (PNSQA study) include significant land area in Canada. For these two watersheds (SITE_NO = 12212001 and 12212450), land-cover data was downloaded from the British Columbia Data Catalogue (Ministry of Forests, Lands, Natural Resource Operations and Rural Development, 2014) and are included in NLCD11 land-cover percentages for those watersheds (not used for riparian zone calculations as they were completely within the U.S.). The land-cover categories in Canada were slightly different from the NLCD11 classifications; therefore, the Canadian classes were fit to the best equivalent in the NLCD11. For example, the Canadian data had an "Annual Crops" classification, which was considered equivalent to the NLCD11 "Cultivated Crops" classification. However, all other variables processed for those watersheds include only the area within the U.S., as equivalent data sources were not available for Canada.
dataqual.complete:
Not all sites are represented in the Riparian dataset because ecology sampling did not take place at these sites due to safety considerations related to high-flow conditions at the time of sampling.
Some environmental characteristics that were geoprocessed for RSQA have been excluded from this dataset because they were not commonly used in the interpretation of the water-quality and ecological sampled data.

horizpa.horizpar:
RSQA sites: The site-specific characteristics are based on the geographic coordinates extracted from the USGS NWIS database as of 5/2/16 (MSQA and SESQA). Although most of the sites are located on the creek or stream, some appear to be offset from the stream centerline based on the available imagery (ESRI and others, 2014). For the final three study region site locations, the longitude and latitude of the sampling location reflect the actual location where the QW sample was collected.
RSQA watershed boundaries: See the "Logical_Consistency_Report" section.
RSQA riparian boundaries: The riparian-zone boundaries were created by buffering lines representing riparian reaches that were digitized from imagery. For a few streams, the stream centerline was difficult to delineate due to canopy cover; in these cases, line features from the high-resolution National Hydrography Dataset (U.S. Geological Survey, 2017a) were used as a visual guide, which may have resulted in a slight offset in the location of the riparian reach, and thus the riparian zone.

vertacc.vertaccr: A formal accuracy assessment of the vertical positional information in the dataset is not applicable.

citeinfo.title: National Hydrography Dataset Plus, Version 2.1 (Elevation Data)

srcinfo.srccontr: The 30-meter resolution (approximately 1:60,000 scale) National Elevation Dataset (NED) in the NHDPlus dataset ("elev_cm") was used to obtain elevation at the site, and mean elevation and slope within the watershed. In addition, the hydrography data (1:100,000 scale) were used in conjunction with these elevation data to compute the slope of the stream segment on which the water-quality site is located. The elevation (NED) data in the NHDPlusV2 is a snapshot of the NED dataset and organized by NHDPlus vector processing units (VPUs). The VPUs and the NED versions (by month and year) used for the RSQA are: VPU 01, VPU 02, VPU 03N, VPU 03S, VPU 03W, VPU 04, VPU 05, VPU 06, VPU 07, VPU 08, VPU 10L, VPU 10U, VPU 17, and VPU 18. The data are being updated continuously so the currentness of the data used corresponds to the year each study was conducted.

procstep.procdesc:
SITE_NO, TSITE_NO, SHORT_NAME, STATION_NM, RSQA_STUDY, QW_LAT, QW_LONG, ECO_LAT, and ECO_LONG:
These variables were exported from the Regional Stream Quality Assessment (RSQA) Project's internal database, on 5/2/16. The Project's site information and other data were harvested from the National Water Information System (NWIS) database (U.S. Geological Survey, 2016) and stored in an Structured Query Language (SQL) Server database that is accessed using Microsoft Access. The site information was exported from Microsoft ACCESS into an EXCEL file, and then the EXCEL file was converted into an ArcGIS geodatabase table using the ArcGIS tool ExcelToTable_conversion (ESRI, 2017). RSQA_STUDY, ECO_LAT and ECO_LONG were added to the project database to represent which study region the data represent and the location of ecological sampling for sites.

CSA_Name and URBAN_CENTER:
These site-specific characteristics were processed by overlaying the RSQA sites with Combined Statistical Areas (CSA) from the U.S. Census (U.S. Census, 2017a) to determine the CSA_Name. This was the primary grouping framework for determining the URBAN_CENTER. It is possible that urban land use (and agricultural land use) in one region or major population center might result in different patterns in chemical occurrence and biological response than in another region or population center. To facilitate these geographic comparisons, major urban centers were assigned to sites. Note, not all sites are associated with an urban center. Ideally, 10 or more sites were available that could define a gradient in urban land use for a single major metropolitan area. Urban centers with fewer sites were Washington, DC, Providence, RI, Albany, NY, and Greenville, SC. Custom urban groupings were created for sites in the Midwest (all 12 targeted sites classified as urban) and western Upstate NY (combining sites in or near Rochester and Syracuse) that are associated with multiple urban centers.

BasinGIS_km2 and EcoReach_km:
These variables represent area of the watershed and the length of the riparian reach, respectively. These variables are from the attribute tables of the RSQA watershed and riparian-zone boundary geodatasets (Qi and Nakagaki, 2020). The areas of the watersheds were calculated within the GIS using the XTools application (Data East, 2017) Calculate Geometry tool. The length of these digitized riparian reaches is approximately equal to the base-10 logarithm of the geospatially computed watershed area.

SITE_Ecoregions3_CODE, SITE_Ecoregions3_NAME, Elev_atQWsite, and GolfCourseArea:
These final, site-specific characteristics were processed by overlaying the water-quality sampling sites with the polygons or grid cells of a thematic or quantitative data layer (study boundary, ecoregions, and elevation) to identify the intersecting grid cell or polygon in which the site is located. The value of the intersecting grid cell or polygon is the resulting characteristic for that site. The NAWQA area-characterization tool (NACT) PointOverlayPolygonToTable_nact (Price, 2012) was used to run the overlay process and calculate SITE_Ecoregions3_CODE, SITE_Ecoregions3_NAME, and GolfCourseArea; the NAWQA area-characterization tool (NACT) PointOverlayRasterToTable_nact (Price, 2012) was used to calculate Elev_atQWsite.

OpenWater2011, DevelopedOpen2011, DevelopedLow2011, DevelopedMed2011, DevelopedHigh2011, BarrenLand2011, DeciduousForest2011, EvergreenForest2011, MixedForest2011, ShrubScrub2011, GrasslandHerb2011, PastureHay2011, CultivatedCrops2011, WoodyWetlands2011, EmerHerbWetlands2011, and SumAreaNLCD2011:
The percentage land-cover classification within a watershed was determined by dividing the number of grid cells classified as each land cover (U.S. Geological Survey, 2014a; Ministry of Forests, Lands, Natural Resource Operations and Rural Development, 2014) in the watershed by the total number of 30-m resolution grid cells in the watershed, then multiplying the quotient by 100. The NAWQA area-characterization tool (NACT), TabulateFeaturesToPercent_nact (Price, 2012) was used to calculate these variables. The SumAreaNLCD2011 variable is the GIS calculated area of all grid cells within the watershed.

Canopy2011, Imperviousness2001, Imperviousness2006, and Imperviousness2011:
The mean percentage tree canopy and developed impervious area in the watershed are represented by the mean of all the grid cell values of the percent impervious area and percent tree canopy within the watershed. The NAWQA area-characterization tool (NACT), FeatureStatisticsToTable_nact (Price, 2012) with the MEAN option was used to calculate these variables.

Dev_CommServices2012, Dev_IndusMilitary2012, Dev_MajorTransp2012, Dev_Other2012, Dev_Recreation2012, Dev_ResidHigh2012, Dev_ResidLowMed2012, SemiDev_AnthroOth2012, SemiDev_UrbHigh2012, SemiDev_UrbLowMed2012, Prod_Crops2012, Prod_GrazingPot2012, Prod_Mining2012, Prod_PastureHay2012, LowUse2012, VeryLowUse_Conserv2012, Water2012, Wetlands2012, SumAreaNWALT2012, Dense_urban, Total_Urban, CSQA_Total_Urban, Extended_Urban, Crops, Total_Ag, Total_Developed, and Total_low_Use:
The percentage land-cover classification within a watershed was determined by dividing the number of grid cells classified as each land use (Falcone, 2015) in the watershed by the total number of 60-m resolution grid cells in the watershed, then multiplying the quotient by 100. The NAWQA area-characterization tool (NACT), TabulateFeaturesToPercent_nact (Price, 2012) was used to calculate these variables. The SumAreaNWALTXXXX variable is the GIS calculated area of all grid cells within the watershed. The Xs represent land-use year (1974,1982, 1992, 2002, and 2012). Dense_urban, Total_Urban, CSQA_Total_Urban (used specifically for CSQA sites in all reports), Extended_Urban, Crops, Total_Ag, Total_Developed, and Total_low_Use are summations of selected land-use variables (see Entity and Attribute section and data dictionary for details).

LU_cat and Major_LU:
These variables are defined using various combinations of the above land-use summations.

UrbanAge_PCT_1940, UrbanAge_PCT_1950, UrbanAge_PCT_1960, UrbanAge_PCT_1970, UrbanAge_PCT_1980, UrbanAge_PCT_1990, UrbanAge_PCT_2000, UrbanAge_PCT_2010, UrbanAge_mean, UrbanAge_PCT_NonUrban, and UrbanAge_SUM_AREA:
The percentage urban-age classification within a watershed was determined by dividing the number of grid cells classified as each urban age (Falcone, 2017a) in the watershed by the total number of 100-m resolution grid cells in the watershed, then multiplying the quotient by 100. The NAWQA area-characterization tool (NACT), TabulateFeaturesToPercent_nact (Price, 2012) was used to calculate these variables. The UrbanAge_SUM_AREA variable is the GIS calculated area of all grid cells within the watershed. UrbanAge_mean and UrbanAge_PCT_NonUrban are summations of selected urban-age variables (see Entity and Attribute section and data dictionary for details).

DamDensity2009, DamDensity2016, DamMajDensity2009, and DamMajDensity2016:
These variables were calculated by intersecting the dam locations with watersheds, determining the total number of dams in the watershed, dividing the total by the area of the watershed, then multiplying the quotient by 100 (because the units are number of dams per 100 square kilometer). The ArcGIS tools used to calculate these variables were Intersect_analysis, Frequency_analysis, JoinField_management, AddField_management, and CalculateField_management (ESRI, 2017) for 2009. For DamDensity2016, the GIS tool TabulateIntersection_analsysis was used. For DamMajDensity2009 and DamMajDensity2016, the same processes were used after points attributed as "major" were selected.

DamNIDstorage2009, DamNIDstorage2016, DamNORMALstorage2009, and DamNORMALstorage2016, NumDams2009, NumDams2016, DamNumMajDams2009, and DamNumMajDams2016:
These variables were calculated by intersecting the dam locations with watersheds, summing the dam storage (from the field, "NID_STORAGE" or "NORM_STORAGE") in the watershed, multiplying by 1.2334818553 to convert from acre-feet to megaliters, then dividing by the area of the watershed (because the units are megaliters total storage per square kilometer). The ArcGIS tools used to calculate these variables were Intersect_analysis, Frequency_analysis, JoinField_management, AddField_management, and CalculateField_management (ESRI, 2017) for the 2009 data. For the 2016 data, the GIS tool TabulateIntersection_analysis was used. For NumDams2009 and NumDams2016, the number of points within each watershed were counted using the GIS tool TabulateIntersection_analysis. For DamNumMajDams2009 and DamNumMajDams2016, the same processes were used after points attributed as "major" were selected.

BaseFlowIndex, DunneOverlandFlow, HortonOverlandFlow, IndexSubsFlowContact, RunoffXXXX, TopogWetnessIndex, DepthToWaterTable, AvailWaterCapacity, BulkDensity, Elev_MeanWatershed, Slope, SRL25Agland, Permeability, OrganicMatter, SandContent, SiltContent, ClayContent, KfactorUpperHorizon, RainfallErosivity, SoilLoss_Afactor, SoilThickness, PopDensity1990, PopDensity2000, PopDensity2010, HousingDensity2000, HousingDensity2010, and AdjHouseIncome_mean:
These variables were determined by calculating the mean value of all the grid cell values of each dataset that fall within the watershed. The NAWQA area-characterization tool (NACT), FeatureStatisticsToTable_nact (Price, 2012) with the MEAN option was used to calculate these variables. The "XXXX" for the Runoff variable represents the year for which the runoff values were calculated.

RoadDensity2013, RoadDensity2014, RoadDensity2015, RoadDensity2016, RoadDensity2017, StreamDensity, Stream_Ephemeral, Stream_Intermittent, Stream_Perennial, and Stream_StreamRiver:
These variables were calculated by clipping the roads or the hydrography lines to the watershed boundary, adding up the lengths of the clipped line segments within the watershed, then dividing the total length by the watershed area. To determine the percentage of streams coded as Ephemeral, Intermittent, Perennial, or StreamRiver, the hydrography lines attributed with an Fcode = 46007, 46003, 46006, and 46000, respectively, were extracted. The ArcGIS tools used to process these variables were Clip_analysis; AddGeometryAttributes_management; JoinField_management; AddField_managment; and CalculateField_management (ESRI, 2017).

N_FertFarm2012, N_FertNonFarm2012, N_Manure2012, P_FertFarm2012, P_FertNonFarm2012, and P_Manure2012:
These six variables were calculated by apportioning the county-level nutrient input data to the watersheds, areally weighting the county fertilizer-use values based on the amount of agricultural (for fertilizer application amount) or urban land (for non-farm fertilizer application amount) from the 2011 National Land Cover Database (Homer and others, 2015), using the land-cover-weighted areal interpolation method (Nakagaki and others, 2013). The NAWQA area-characterization tools (NACT), FeatureWeightsToTable_nact, PartialAreaWeights_nact, and CalculateWeightedStatistics_nact (Price, 2012) were used to estimate the nitrogen or phosphorus input within the watersheds.

N_Wastewater1992, N_Wastewater1997, N_WasteWater2002, P_Wastewater1992, P_Wastewater1997, P_WasteWater2002, N_NPDES_2012, NumFacilities2012, NumMajorFacilities2012, and P_NPDES_2012:
For data from 1992, 1997, and 2002, these variables were calculated by intersecting wastewater facility locations (Maupin and Ivahnenko, 2011; Robertson and Saad, 2013) with watersheds, summing the estimated nitrogen or phosphorus load of wastewater discharge into the watershed, then dividing the total by the area of the watershed. The ArcGIS tools used to calculate these variables were Intersect_analysis and Frequency_analysis (ESRI, 2017). For the 2012 data, the variables were calculated by intersecting ALL facility (not just wastewater facilities) locations (Skinner and Wise, 2019) with watersheds, summing the estimated nitrogen or phosphorus load discharge into the watershed, then dividing the total by the area of the watershed.

Total_N and Total_P:
These variables are sums of various individual watershed nutrient input variables (see Entity and Attribute section and data dictionary for details).

N_AtmosphDepos2013, N_AtmosphDepos2014, N_AtmosphDepos2015, N_AtmosphDepos2016 and N_AtmosphDepos2017:
These variables were determined by calculating the mean atmospheric (wet) deposition of total inorganic nitrogen from nitrate value of all the grid cell values of each dataset that fall within the watershed. The NAWQA area-characterization tool (NACT), FeatureStatisticsToTable_nact (Price, 2012) with the MEAN option was used to calculate these variables.

TRI_NumOfChems2010, TRI_NumOfFacil, TRI_NumOfSuperFund and TRI_SumLbs2010:
These variables were calculated by intersecting locations stored in the Toxic Release Inventory (TRI) database with watersheds, summing the number of sites and the pounds of chemicals released in the watershed. The ArcGIS tool used to calculate these variables was TabulateIntersection_analysis.

All variables starting with "LB_" (lower basin):
These variables were processed in the same manner stated in the process steps for the watersheds but were processed only for the areas representing the lower 5km of the watershed. The polygons representing lower basins can be found in Qi and Nakagaki, 2020.

All variables starting with "r50_" (50m riparian buffer):
These variables were processed in the same manner stated in the process steps for the watersheds but were processed only for the areas representing a riparian zone (50m buffer around a digitized stream center line). The polygons representing riparian zones can be found in Qi and Nakagaki, 2020.

enttyp.enttypd: Data dictionary containing variable names, definitions, methods, and sources. Information not applicable to a variable is denoted by "n/a.” Please refer to this file for further details about the variables.

attr.attrdef: Units
attr.attrdefs: U.S. Geological Survey

attr.attrdef: Time period of dataset content, expressed as years

attr.attrdefs: U.S. Geological Survey

attr.attrdef: Notes regarding the geospatial data used for calculations, or any preparatory work conducted to compile the data prior to characterization processing.

attr.attrdef: Description of the method used for geoprocessing
attr.attrdefs: U.S. Geological Survey

attr.attrdef: Short name for the method
attr.attrdefs: U.S. Geological Survey

attr.attrdef: ArcGis-specific geoprocessing tool name used to derive the characteristic
attr.attrdefs: U.S. Geological Survey

attr.attrdef: Mean year of the start of urban development. Defined by the formula =IF(UrbanAge_PCT_NonUrban <100,(((2005*UrbanAge_PCT_2010) + (1995*UrbanAge_PCT_2000) + (1985*UrbanAge_PCT_1990) + (1975*UrbanAge_PCT_1980) + (1965*UrbanAge_PCT_1970) + (1955*UrbanAge_PCT_1960) + (1945*UrbanAge_PCT_1950) + (1935*UrbanAge_PCT_1940))/(100- UrbanAge_PCT_NonUrban)),0). If the watershed was not overlain by any urban area, the value is NULL.
attr.attrdefs: Project defined

overview.eaover: A data dictionary has been provided for details on variables in this dataset. Highlighted in the metadata document are the variables processed for whole watersheds. These same variables were processed for two studies (NESQA and CSQA) for the lower 5-km of the watershed (not detailed here since the definitions are the same even though values are different); these variables have the same name but are preceded with "LB_". A select number of the variables were processed for the riparian zones (not detailed here since the definitions are the same) and have the same name but are preceded with "r50_".

cntaddr.address: Denver Federal Center, Building 810, Mail Stop 302

distinfo.distliab: Unless otherwise stated, all data, metadata and related materials are considered to satisfy the quality standards relative to the purpose for which the data were collected. Although these data and associated metadata have been reviewed for accuracy and completeness and approved for release by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the display or utility of the data for other purposes, nor on all computer systems, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. Any use of trade, firm, or product names is for descriptive purposes only and does not imply endorsement by the U.S. Government.
